Robert Watkins wrote:

> Okay, I tried exactly that, and you're right, it didn't work... but
> the one I used did. I did some digging, and I found out something
> interesting: it works if your TestCase takes a String constructor.
>
> [...]
> Why it works with a string constructor but not with an Object (or a
> double... tried both) I dunno.

Very cool.  It works because it happens to survive this code from 
RemoteTestRunner.java:

        Class[] classArgs= { String.class };
       //...
                constructor= testClass.getConstructor(classArgs);

I'm sure the original intent was simply to handle the standard override 
of TestCase(String name), but the fact that it works for any test class 
with a String constructor might be a huge help for others using 
parameterized classes.

    David Saff
